Quick search

Page 6 of 7

Best practice

The best practices in this section adhere to publishing standards based around findability, preserving the content and ethical publishing practices.

We encourage journals to adopt these best practices as far as possible but they are not mandatory for DOAJ indexing.

Archiving policy

Long-term preservation service(s) with which the journal is currently archived 

Select at least one:

Archiving policy

“Long-term preservation service(s) with which the journal is currently archived”

Only active archiving is accepted; content must be actively deposited in each of the options you choose. If the journal is registered with a service but archiving is not yet active, choose No.

PubMed Central covers PMC U.S.A., PMC Canada, and PMC Europe (Wellcome Trust).

Name of the national library

Link to the preservation and archiving information on the journal’s site

Repository policy

Where is the journal’s policy allowing authors to deposit the AAM or VOR registered? 

Select at least one:

Repository policy

“Where is the journal’s policy allowing authors to deposit the AAM or VOR registered?”

AAM stands for Author Accepted Manuscript. VOR is the Version of Record.

This questions ask whether or not the journal allows authors to deposit a copy of their work in an institutional repository.

If the journal allows authors to do this, is that policy registered in a policy directory?

Link to the repository policy on the journal’s site

Unique identifiers & structured data

Persistent article identifiers used by the journal 

Select at least one:

Unique identifiers & structured data

“Persistent article identifiers used by the journal”

A persistent article identifier (PID) is used to find the article no matter where it is located. The most common type of PID is the digital object identifier (DOI).

Read more about PIDs.

Does the journal allow for ORCID iDs to be present in article metadata? 

Unique identifiers & structured data

“Does the journal allow for ORCID iDs to be present in article metadata?”

An ORCID (Open Researcher and Contributor) iD is an alphanumeric code to uniquely identify authors.

Does the journal comply with I4OC standards for open citations? 

Unique identifiers & structured data

“Does the journal comply with I4OC standards for open citations?”

The I4OC standards ask that citations are structured, separable, and open.
